Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>The NN activations generally don't take up significant computation 
>time.  We can run 50 networks at the same time in real-time easily 
>on a single processor.  Obviously at some huge network size things 
>will start slowing down, but then again, what else can you do if a 
>huge network is necessary to solve the task?
>
>  
>
There is also the possibility of implementing networks in hardware 
and/or distributing them over multiple processors if needs be. So if 
someone did evolve a network that helped significantly with some task 
that had commercial worth but it was too slow on a general purpose CPU 
then there are other options available. One relatively cheap method 
might be to use FPGAs, I'm sure that I've read about these being used 
for neural nets in the past - you can get FPGAs on a standard PCI card I 
believe.

Colin.
